title: 111_hr4250
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The "Medicaid DSH Integrity Act" recognizes the importance of Medicaid DSH payments for safety net hospitals serving low-income individuals. Reporting and auditing requirements ensure proper use of funds. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services issued regulations implementing reporting and auditing requirements for Medicaid DSH funds, which narrowed the scope of DSH payments for many States. Congress did not intend to change the definition of DSH-eligible costs or limit DSH payments under the existing program. The regulations implementing reporting and auditing requirements for Medicaid DSH funds could lead to significant payment reductions for safety net providers. Congress did not intend to change the definition of DSH-eligible costs or limit DSH payments under the existing program. Revision of Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with States and disproportionate share hospitals, will not enforce changes in policy regarding the calculation of limits under the Social Security Act. An interim final rule will be published to revise the Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations as necessary. The interim final rule will revise Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations to correct policy changes related to limit calculations under the Social Security Act and provide guidance for implementation. Regulatory changes will allow inclusion of all costs for services to individuals without health insurance. The new interim final rule will include regulatory changes allowing hospitals to include all costs related to services provided to uninsured patients, regardless of other insurance coverage. States will be permitted to use their own definition of allowable costs in Medicaid plans for computing purposes. CMS will allow States to use their definition of allowable costs in Medicaid plans for computing purposes, as long as the costs do not exceed Medicare principles of cost reimbursement. The audit requirement for inpatient and outpatient hospital services will be interpreted consistently with the term "hospital services" in the Social Security Act. CMS will revise regulations to allow alternative methodologies for determining actual costs in Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting, including trending forward costs from prior years. CMS will revise regulations to permit alternative methodologies for determining actual costs in Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting, including trending forward costs from prior years. Additionally, the Social Security Act will be amended to update the initiation requirements to be effective as if included in the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. The Act defines key terms such as CMS, Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations, Medicaid DSH program, and Secretary.
